text: However, certain events may prevent a statement from completing normally: The break ( §14.15 ), continue ( §14.16 ), and return ( §14.17 ) statements cause a transfer of control that may prevent normal completion of statements that contain them.

modals.context: , certain events may prevent a statement
of control that may prevent normal completion

components.subject: statement completion
consequences: normal completion of containing statements is prevented

formal_logic:
∀s,stmt: (
  (∃b: Runtime(Contains(stmt,break(b))) ∨
   ∃c: Runtime(Contains(stmt,continue(c))) ∨
   ∃r: Runtime(Contains(stmt,return(r))))
  ∧ Contains(s,stmt)
  → (Runtime(TransferControl(stmt)) ∧ ¬NormalCompletion(s))

text: Evaluation of certain expressions may throw exceptions from the Java Virtual Machine ( §15.6 ).

modals.context: of certain expressions may throw exceptions from

components.subject: certain expressions
consequences: exceptions from JVM can be thrown

formal_logic:
∀e,x: (Runtime(Evaluation(e)) → ∃x: (Exception(x) ∧ Throws(e,x)))

This formalizes that for all expressions e and exceptions x, if there is a runtime evaluation of expression e, then there exists some exception x that can be thrown by that expression.

text: An explicit throw ( §14.18 ) statement also results in an exception.
formal_logic: ∀s,e: (Runtime(s) ∧ ThrowStatement(s) ∧ ExplicitThrow(s)) → ProducesException(s,e)

text: An exception causes a transfer of control that may prevent normal completion of statements.

modals.context: of control that may prevent normal completion

components.subject: exception
consequences: normal completion of statements may be prevented

formal_logic:
∀e,s,m: (Runtime(e) ∧ Exception(e) ∧ Statement(s) ∧ Method(m) ∧ ExecutesIn(s,m)) → 
(∃tc: TransferControl(tc,e) ∧ 
(¬NormalCompletion(s) ∨ NormalCompletion(s)))

Where:
Exception(e) represents an exception
Statement(s) represents a program statement
TransferControl(tc,e) represents a transfer of control caused by exception e
NormalCompletion(s) represents normal completion of statement s
ExecutesIn(s,m) represents a statement executing within method m

text: If such an event occurs, then execution of one or more statements may be terminated before all steps of their normal mode of execution have completed; such statements are said to complete abruptly .

modals.context: or more statements may be terminated before

components.subject: statement execution
consequences: normal execution steps may not complete fully

formal_logic:
∀s,e: Runtime(s) ∧ Runtime(e) ∧ StatementExecution(s) ∧ Event(e) ∧ Occurs(e) → 
(∃steps: NormalExecution(steps) ∧ (Terminates(s,steps) ∨ IncompleteExecution(steps)) ∧ AbruptCompletion(s))

text: An abrupt completion always has an associated reason , which is one of the following: A break with no label A break with a given label A continue with no label A continue with a given label A return with no value A return with a given value A throw with a given value, including exceptions thrown by the Java Virtual Machine The terms "complete normally" and "complete abruptly" also apply to the evaluation of expressions ( §15.6 ).

components.subject: abrupt completion
conditions: Must have one of the specified reasons

formal_logic:
∀x,r: Runtime(x) ∧ AbruptCompletion(x) → 
  ∃r: Reason(r) ∧ (
    (BreakNoLabel(r) ∨
    ∃l: BreakWithLabel(r,l) ∨
    ContinueNoLabel(r) ∨
    ∃l: ContinueWithLabel(r,l) ∨
    ReturnNoValue(r) ∨
    ∃v: ReturnWithValue(r,v) ∨
    ∃v: ThrowWithValue(r,v))
  ) ∧
  (∀e: Expression(e) ∧ Evaluates(e) → 
    (CompletesNormally(e) ∨ CompletesAbruptly(e,r)))

text: The only reason an expression can complete abruptly is that an exception is thrown, because of either a throw with a given value ( §14.18 ) or a run-time exception or error ( §11 ( Exceptions ) , §15.6 ).

components.subject: expression completion
conditions: A throw statement with a given value occurs

formal_logic:
∀e,x: Runtime(e) ∧ CompletesAbruptly(e) → 
  ∃x: (ThrowStatement(x,e) ∨ RuntimeException(x) ∨ RuntimeError(x)) ∧ 
      Throws(e,x) ∧ 
      ExceptionThrown(x)

text: If a statement evaluates an expression, abrupt completion of the expression always causes the immediate abrupt completion of the statement, with the same reason.

components.subject: statement with expression evaluation
consequences: statement preserves the same completion reason as the expression

formal_logic: ∀s,e,r: Statement(s) ∧ Expression(e) ∧ Contains(s,e) ∧ Runtime(AbruptlyCompletes(e,r)) → Runtime(AbruptlyCompletes(s,r))

text: Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, abrupt completion of a substatement causes the immediate abrupt completion of the statement itself, with the same reason, and all succeeding steps in the normal mode of execution of the statement are not performed.

components.subject: statement execution
conditions: no other specification overrides this behavior
consequences: immediate abrupt completion of the parent statement
remaining normal execution steps are skipped
exceptions: when otherwise specified in the chapter

formal_logic:
∀s,sub,r: Statement(s) ∧ Substatement(sub,s) ∧ Runtime(execution) ∧ 
(AbruptCompletion(sub,r) ∧ ¬HasOverride(s,"completion")) →
(AbruptCompletion(s,r) ∧ 
 SameReason(s.completion,sub.completion) ∧ 
 ¬ExecuteRemainingSteps(s))

where:
Statement(s): s is a statement
Substatement(sub,s): sub is a substatement of s
AbruptCompletion(x,r): x completes abruptly with reason r
HasOverride(s,rule): s has an override for the specified rule
SameReason(c1,c2): completion reasons c1 and c2 are identical
ExecuteRemainingSteps(s): remaining steps of s are executed

text: Unless otherwise specified, a statement completes normally if all expressions it evaluates and all substatements it executes complete normally.

components.subject: statement
conditions: all expressions it evaluates complete normally
all substatements it executes complete normally

formal_logic:
∀s,e,sub: Runtime(s) ∧ 
(¬ExplicitlySpecified(s) ∧ 
(∀e: Evaluates(s,e) → CompletesNormally(e)) ∧ 
(∀sub: Executes(s,sub) → CompletesNormally(sub))) 
→ CompletesNormally(s)

text: However, certain events may prevent a statement from completing normally: The break , yield , continue , and return statements ( §14.15 , §14.21 , §14.16 , §14.17 ) cause a transfer of control that may prevent normal completion of expressions, statements, and blocks that contain them.

modals.context: , certain events may prevent a statement
of control that may prevent normal completion

components.subject: statement completion
consequences: normal completion of expressions may be prevented
normal completion of statements may be prevented
normal completion of blocks may be prevented

formal_logic:
∀s,e,b: (
  Runtime(s) ∧ (
    (∃x: (HasBreakStatement(x,s) ∨ HasYieldStatement(x,s) ∨ HasContinueStatement(x,s) ∨ HasReturnStatement(x,s))) →
    (
      TransferControl(s) ∧
      (ContainsExpression(e,s) → ¬NormalCompletion(e)) ∧
      (ContainsStatement(s,s) → ¬NormalCompletion(s)) ∧
      (ContainsBlock(b,s) → ¬NormalCompletion(b))
    )
  )
)

text: Evaluation of certain expressions may throw exceptions from the Java Virtual Machine ( §15.6 ).

modals.context: of certain expressions may throw exceptions from

components.subject: expressions
consequences: exceptions from the JVM can be thrown

formal_logic:
∀e,x: Runtime(Evaluate(e)) → ∃ex: (Exception(ex) ∧ Throws(e,ex))

where Evaluate(e) represents expression evaluation and Exception(ex) indicates ex is a JVM exception.

text: An explicit throw ( §14.18 ) statement also results in an exception.
formal_logic: ∀s,e: (Runtime(s) ∧ ThrowStatement(s) ∧ ExplicitThrow(s)) → ResultsInException(s,e)

text: An exception causes a transfer of control that may prevent normal completion of statements.

modals.context: of control that may prevent normal completion

components.subject: exception
consequences: normal completion of statements may be prevented

formal_logic:
∀e,s,t: (Runtime(e) ∧ Exception(e) ∧ Statement(s) ∧ TransferControl(t)) → 
(Occurs(e) → (Causes(e,t) ∧ ∃c: ControlFlow(c) ∧ 
(Prevents(t,NormalCompletion(s)) ∨ ¬Prevents(t,NormalCompletion(s)))))

text: If such an event occurs, then execution of one or more statements may be terminated before all steps of their normal mode of execution have completed; such statements are said to complete abruptly .

modals.context: or more statements may be terminated before

components.subject: statement execution
consequences: steps of normal execution may not complete

formal_logic:
∀s,e: Runtime(s) ∧ Runtime(e) ∧ 
(StatementExecution(s) ∧ Event(e) ∧ Occurs(e)) → 
∃x: (AbruptCompletion(s,x) ∧ 
¬CompleteNormalExecution(s) ∧ 
TerminatedEarly(s))

text: An abrupt completion always has an associated reason , which is one of the following: A break with no label A break with a given label A continue with no label A continue with a given label A return with no value A return with a given value A throw with a given value, including exceptions thrown by the Java Virtual Machine A yield with a given value The terms "complete normally" and "complete abruptly" also apply to the evaluation of expressions ( §15.6 ).

components.subject: abrupt completion
conditions: Must have one of the specified reason types

formal_logic:
∀x,r: Runtime(x) ∧ AbruptCompletion(x) → 
  ∃r: HasReason(x,r) ∧ 
    (BreakNoLabel(r) ∨ 
     BreakWithLabel(r) ∨ 
     ContinueNoLabel(r) ∨ 
     ContinueWithLabel(r) ∨ 
     ReturnNoValue(r) ∨ 
     ReturnWithValue(r) ∨ 
     ThrowWithValue(r) ∨ 
     YieldWithValue(r)) ∧
  ∀e: Expression(e) → (CompletesNormally(e) ∨ CompletesAbruptly(e))

text: The only reason an expression can complete abruptly is that an exception is thrown, because of either a throw with a given value ( §14.18 ) or a run-time exception or error ( §11 ( Exceptions ) , §15.6 ).
formal_logic:
∀e,x: Expression(e) ∧ CompletesAbruptly(e) →
  ∃ex: (Exception(ex) ∧ 
    (
      (∃t: ThrowStatement(t) ∧ Throws(t,ex)) ∨
      (Runtime(ex) ∧ (RuntimeException(ex) ∨ Error(ex)))
    )
  ) ∧
  ∀other: CompletionCause(other) ∧ ¬Exception(other) → ¬CompletesAbruptly(e,other)

text: If a statement evaluates an expression, abrupt completion of the expression always causes the immediate abrupt completion of the statement, with the same reason.

components.subject: statement evaluating an expression
consequences: statement preserves the same completion reason as the expression

formal_logic: ∀s,e,r: (Statement(s) ∧ Expression(e) ∧ Contains(s,e) ∧ Runtime(AbruptlyCompletes(e,r))) → (AbruptlyCompletes(s,r) ∧ CompletionReason(s) = CompletionReason(e))

text: Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, abrupt completion of a substatement causes the immediate abrupt completion of the statement itself, with the same reason, and all succeeding steps in the normal mode of execution of the statement are not performed.

components.subject: statement execution
conditions: no other specification overrides this behavior
consequences: immediate abrupt completion of the parent statement
same reason for completion is maintained
exceptions: when otherwise specified in the chapter

formal_logic:
∀s,sub,r: (
  Statement(s) ∧ 
  Substatement(sub,s) ∧ 
  Runtime(AbruptCompletion(sub,r)) ∧ 
  ¬∃spec: (OverridesBehavior(spec,s)) 
  → 
  (
    Runtime(AbruptCompletion(s,r)) ∧ 
    ¬Runtime(ExecuteRemainingSteps(s)) ∧
    CompletionReason(s) = CompletionReason(sub)
  )
)

text: Unless otherwise specified, a statement completes normally if all expressions it evaluates and all substatements it executes complete normally.

components.subject: statement
conditions: all expressions it evaluates complete normally
all substatements it executes complete normally

formal_logic:
∀s,e,sub: Statement(s) ∧ 
(¬∃spec: SpecialRule(s,spec)) ∧
(∀e: Evaluates(s,e) → CompletesNormally(e)) ∧
(∀sub: Executes(s,sub) → CompletesNormally(sub)) →
CompletesNormally(s)
